conclusion: To determine the collision time, analyze positions over time using v-t graphs.
The x-axis represents time in seconds; the y-axis represents speed in m/s.
Car A's initial velocity is 25 m/s, decelerates to stop over 30 seconds; Car B's initial velocity is 15 m/s, decelerates to stop over 30 seconds.
Both lines intersect at 20 seconds, meaning both cars will stop at that point if they do not collide earlier.
Focus on the point where their positions are equal to find collision time.
Intersection occurs at 20 seconds, where both cars' velocities are zero.
Calculate distance traveled using area under the velocity-time curve.
Distance for Car A is 250 m using area of triangle formula.
Distance for Car B is 150 m using area of triangle formula.
At 20 seconds, Car A has traveled 250 meters, Car B 150 meters; difference is 100 meters.
Distance between them decreases by 10 meters per second.
Relative speed of approach is 40 m/s.
Time to close the 100-meter gap is 2.5 seconds.
Collision occurs 2.5 seconds after 20 seconds, i.e., 22.5 seconds after braking starts.
